author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Hudson Whiskey Releases Its Oldest Bourbon Blend
description: Four Part Harmony is a bourbon, aged for seven years, made with corn, rye, wheat and malted barley.
content: In the rolling farmland outside New Paltz, N.Y., is a former gristmill, now the Tuthilltown Spirits Distillery, where Hudson Whiskey is made. One of New York’s first craft distillers, it started with bourbon more than 10 years ago and now it has introduced its longest-aged example, Four Part Harmony, a seven-year-old bourbon made with four grains. (To be labeled bourbon in the United States, the whiskey must be made from at least 51 percent corn and be aged in charred new oak barrels.) This amber whiskey — with a honeyed, hazelnut nose and a mellow richness — combines 60 percent corn, 15 percent each of rye and wheat, and 10 percent malted barley. It’s not the distillery’s first four-grain whiskey, but it’s the oldest, and is a perfect sip on an autumn evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Trump Missed the Part About No Do-Overs
description: And apparently no one from his party is going to explain it to him.
content: Bret Stephens: Gail, I know we don’t typically talk about office politics, but sometimes it’s hard to avoid — as when our friend and colleague Nick Kristof leaves us to run for governor of his home state of Oregon. Our readers ought to know what an incredible guy he is behind the scenes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: After a Chaotic Week, the Raiders Post an Efficient Win
description: With Coach Rich Bisaccia in charge, Las Vegas was calm and effective against the Broncos despite the recent turmoil after Jon Gruden’s resignation as coach last week.
content: DENVER — As Rich Bisaccia ran out of the stadium’s tunnel before his team played the Denver Broncos on Sunday, a man in a white shirt and yellow hat greeted him with the head coaching headset. The two stood on the sideline for a few minutes while the man helped snake the headset’s cords through Bisaccia’s shirt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: How ‘Fire Shut Up in My Bones’ Brought Step to the Met
description: The opera’s choreographer and co-director, Camille A. Brown, talks about the legacy of the African diaspora and influence of “School Daze” in her dances.
content: Camille A. Brown had a lot of catching up to do. She wasn’t part of the original creative team behind Terence Blanchard’s opera “Fire Shut Up in My Bones” when it was presented in 2019 in St. Louis. But at the Metropolitan Opera, where the production runs through Saturday — the first time a work by a Black composer has been presented there in its 138-year history — her touch is palpable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: America’s Cash Glut
description: The economy is almost doing too well. But there are some problems.
content: Sluggish income growth has been a defining economic problem of recent decades. With only brief exceptions, the incomes of most middle-class and working-class American families have grown frustratingly slowly — trailing well behind economic growth — since the late 1970s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stella Kalinina
title: In Los Angeles, Glimpses of an Oasis With Deep Immigrant Roots
description: The San Pedro Community Gardens have provided physical and spiritual nourishment for the past half a century to multiple generations of immigrant Angelenos.
content: Ten minutes from my home, next to a decommissioned landfill, a freeway and the largest port in the country, sits an unlikely hillside oasis of vegetables and fruit trees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Biden’s Paid Leave Plan at Risk as Lawmakers Look to Shrink Package
description: An initial proposal to offer workers 12 weeks of paid leave could be whittled down as Democrats try to trim their $3.5 trillion social policy bill.
content: WASHINGTON — Christina Hayes, 34, stopped going to the doctor for treatment of her lupus when she was pregnant and working at a cable company in Michigan in 2013. She had used up her vacation days, and without paid sick leave, she worried about paying her rent and electricity bill if she took more time off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: How Lifelong Cholesterol Levels Can Harm or Help Your Heart
description: The longer you have high levels of “bad” LDL cholesterol, the greater your risk of a heart attack.
content: LDL, or “bad” cholesterol, is a major risk factor for coronary heart disease. Now a new study suggests that, like smoking, it has a cumulative effect over a lifetime: The longer a person has high LDL, the greater their risk of suffering a heart attack or cardiac arrest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Jury Selection Begins in Trial Over Ahmaud Arbery’s Killing
description: Whether the three men accused in Mr. Arbery’s death were motived by racism will quite likely be a major theme in the case.
content: BRUNSWICK, Ga. — A complicated jury selection process kicked off Monday in the trial of the three white men accused of murdering Ahmaud Arbery, a Black man they had chased through a coastal Georgia neighborhood, with lawyers sparring over what kinds of questions the hundreds of potential jurors could be subjected to, including questions about their views on race and the Confederate battle flag.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Curb Your Enthusiasm’ and ‘Queens’
description: Season 11 of “Curb Your Enthusiasm” begins on HBO. And a new musical drama series debuts on ABC.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Oct. 18-24. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Risotto for Beginners
description: A new kit from Tasty Ribbon, designed by Fratelli Desideri and the chef Andrea Larossa, offers simple instructions with some high-end garnish.
content: Shelf-stable risotto kits, some even dressed with a whiff of truffle, are fairly common. A new one from Tasty Ribbon is designed for a rank beginner to master. Created by Fratelli Desideri with Andrea Larossa, a chef at the Michelin-starred Larossa in Alba, Italy, the kit incorporates some high-end flourishes like Carnaroli rice, a connoisseur’s choice; freeze-dried mountain cheese; a generous helping of clarified butter for a voluptuous finish; and licorice powder, an uncommon garnish, to add a hint of musky sweetness. The technique is bare bones, leaving no option for adjusting the texture to taste: lightly sauté the rice in extra-virgin olive oil (included), then add a measured amount of boiling salted water all at once and cook, stirring. The cheese and butter go in at the end, and the licorice gets dusted on just before serving. The kit is designed to serve three, but can accommodate four. They do not mention it, but using your choice of stock in place of water is a worthwhile option.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Nuclear Fusion Edges Toward the Mainstream
description: Long-shot money is flowing into start-ups that seek the energy of the stars. Driving the investments is a rising alarm about global warming.
content: ABINGDON, England — Harnessing fusion energy into something commercially viable — and maybe, ultimately, a clean source of power that replaces fossil fuels for centuries to come — has long been considered by some as the ultimate moonshot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays and Zachary Small
title: Jefferson Statue Will Be Removed From N.Y.C. Council Chambers
description: After a debate over Jefferson’s legacy and his history as a slaveholder, city officials delayed deciding on where to display the statue.
content: For more than 100 years, a 7-foot-tall statue of Thomas Jefferson has towered over members of the New York City Council in their chamber at City Hall, a testament to his role as one of the nation’s founding fathers and the primary author of the Declaration of Independence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Is Mark Zuckerberg a Man Without Principles?
description: The veteran tech journalist Walt Mossberg unpacks the Facebook Files with historical context and personal anecdotes.
content: After leaked internal documents in The Wall Street Journal, whistle-blower testimony on Capitol Hill, a global server outage and drops in share price, Facebook has recently taken (another) spectacular beating. But the veteran tech journalist Walt Mossberg says none of it has been a surprise. A longtime friend and mentor of Kara Swisher, he tells her, “I think the company is fundamentally unethical.” And, drawing on his experience covering controversial leaders, including Steve Jobs and Bill Gates (as he calls them, “the old guard”), Mossberg says the Facebook C.E.O. is still an aberration: “In my encounters with Mark Zuckerberg, I’ve never been able to discover any principles.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: In Two Rulings, Supreme Court Bolsters Legal Shield for Police
description: The unsigned decisions, without noted dissents, indicated that the court continued to support the widely criticized doctrine of qualified immunity.
content: WASHINGTON — In two unsigned decisions without noted dissents, the Supreme Court on Monday ruled in favor of police officers accused of using excessive force. The rulings were a signal that the court continues to support the doctrine of qualified immunity, which can shield police misconduct from lawsuits seeking damages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Luke Broadwater
title: Trump Sues to Block Release of White House Papers to Jan. 6 Inquiry
description: The case raises novel constitutional questions about the scope of an ex-president’s executive privilege powers if the current president disagrees.
content: WASHINGTON — Former President Donald J. Trump sued Congress and the National Archives on Monday, seeking to block the disclosure of White House files related to his actions and communications surrounding the Jan. 6 Capitol riot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: A ‘Holy Grail’ of American Folk Art, Hiding in Plain Sight
description: A collector’s keen eye — and willingness to knock on a stranger’s door — led to the rediscovery of a sculpture by a renowned stone carver, William Edmondson.
content: John Foster was driving through St. Louis in 2019 when he spotted something unusual on the front porch of a home just east of Forest Park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola, Sopan Deb and Alanis Thames
title: N.B.A. West Preview: The Return of ‘Beautiful Basketball’
description: With an improved Golden State and the new-look Lakers, the Western Conference could be unpredictable — and fun.
content: There were years when fans generally knew what to expect from the Western Conference. Everyone knew the Showtime-era Lakers would reach the finals. Everyone knew Timmy, Manu and Pop would have the Spurs contending late in the season. Everyone knew the Mailman would deliver — at least until the Jazz met Michael Jordan and the Bulls. And, more recently, everyone knew the Splash Brothers had Golden State primed for championship runs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Washington Metro Pulls Most Train Cars From Service After Derailment
description: The Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority idled 748 Metro cars on Monday after one train derailed at least three times on Oct. 12, officials said.
content: The Metro system in Washington pulled more than half of its subway cars from service before the Monday morning commute as federal investigators scrutinized a surge in train-alignment “failures” and the derailment of one train at least three times in a single day last week, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Russia Breaks Diplomatic Ties With NATO
description: Moscow’s decision to end its diplomatic mission to the alliance will end a long, post-Cold War experiment in building trust between militaries.
content: MOSCOW — Russia plans to cease its diplomatic engagement with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the Russian foreign minister said on Monday, in the latest sign of unraveling relations between Moscow and the West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: What Scientists Know About the Risk of Breakthrough Covid Deaths
description: Deaths among people who have been fully vaccinated remain rare, but older adults and those with compromised immune systems are at much higher risk.
content: The death of former Secretary of State Colin Powell on Monday from complications of Covid-19 has provided fuel for vaccine skeptics and opponents, who immediately seized on the news that Mr. Powell had been vaccinated to stoke doubts about the effectiveness of the vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: For L.S.U., Not Winning Enough Is the Biggest Scandal
description: Louisiana State said “wins and losses on the field” led to Coach Ed Orgeron’s dismissal, but he seemed determined to tempt fate in other ways.
content: It was less than two years ago, in the wee hours of the morning in New Orleans after the Louisiana State football team had capped a perfect season and the party had moved onto Bourbon Street, that Ed Orgeron walked alone with his wife, Kelly, across a Superdome field littered with confetti.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Egan
title: Elizabeth Strout Gets Meta in Her New Novel About Marriage
description: The protagonist of “Oh William!” is a famous author whose books have a lot in common with ones written by the creator of Lucy Barton.
content: OH WILLIAM! By Elizabeth Strout
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Colin Powell, Who Shaped U.S. National Security, Dies at 84
description: A former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, secretary of state and national security adviser, Mr. Powell died of complications of Covid-19, his family said.
content: [Follow the latest coverage of the death of Colin Powell.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: In Queens, Fiery Aguachile Lives in a Yellow Submarine
description: Mariscos El Submarino, in Jackson Heights, specializes in the seafood dish from Mexico’s west coast.
content: Serious is not the word that springs immediately to mind when you arrive at Mariscos El Submarino, a seafood restaurant on Roosevelt Avenue in Queens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Sepp
title: I’m the President of the National Taxpayers Union. Be Careful With I.R.S. Reform.
description: The I.R.S. needs more resources. But it also needs to protect taxpayer rights.
content: Democratic lawmakers plan to boost the Internal Revenue Service’s enforcement authority to help pay for the spending package working through Congress. But while the I.R.S. needs more funding to fulfill its mission, the current version of the reform legislation would run roughshod over decades of taxpayer protections that were enshrined by huge bipartisan majorities.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Submit Your Crossword Puzzles to The New York Times
description: The New York Times looks for intelligent, literate, entertaining and well-crafted crosswords that appeal to the broad range of Times solvers.
content: A New York Times crossword will be a collaboration between you and our staff of editors, who will seek to preserve your voice while making the puzzle as enjoyable as possible for solvers. This page of guidelines is a living document and reflects our current best practices on crossword construction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: The Busiest Port in the U.S.
description: The Port of Los Angeles plays a major role in the global supply chain. Here’s what has gone wrong.
content: When you think of Los Angeles, the first thing that comes to mind probably isn’t a massive, industrial shipping hub.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove
title: As Rents Rise, So Do Pressures on People at Risk of Eviction
description: The end of the federal ban on evictions came amid soaring rents that make it harder for people to find new places to live.
content: ATLANTA — Every time Jeffery Jones hears a noise outside his house, his heart skips a beat. Since his landlord directed the county to evict him, his fiancée and their 2-year-old son from their modest gray house in the Atlanta suburb of Loganville, Ga., it is just a matter of time before the noise he hears is the knock of a sheriff’s deputy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Chang Chien and Amy Qin
title: Taiwan Couple Are Suspected of Negligent Homicide in Building Fire
description: Prosecutors accused a woman of leaving a burning incense coil unattended in the building in Kaohsiung. Her partner was accused of failing to remind her to douse the coil before leaving.
content: CHIAYI, Taiwan — Taiwanese prosecutors said that a couple were suspected of setting a fire and negligent homicide after 46 people were killed and dozens of others injured last week in the island’s deadliest building blaze in more than two decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: College Degrees Are Overrated
description: Employers are missing out on a large talent pool by insisting on diplomas for jobs that don’t require them.
content: Recruiters are insisting on college degrees for jobs that don’t need them. Why? Risk aversion. If recruiters recommend a non-graduate who doesn’t work out, they’ll get blamed. Whereas, if they reject a non-graduate who would have been a huge success — well, no one will ever know, will they? It’s a costly but undetectable mistake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: How Has Home Cooking Changed in the Pandemic?
description: Les Dames d’Escoffier NY will host a virtual discussion with the chef Marcus Samuelsson and the writer Grace Young on the new realities of kitchen life.
content: In their series of discussions called the Next Big Bite, Les Dames d’Escoffier NY, a nonprofit educational and advocacy organization, has scheduled a one-hour virtual panel on Oct. 21 to explore the ever-evolving changes that the pandemic brought about for home cooking and restaurant dining. The lineup includes the chef Marcus Samuelsson and the writer Grace Young as keynote speakers, with the food entrepreneurs Jane M. Freiman, Samuel Dennigan, Eve Turow-Paul and Karen Washington on the panel led by Tara Bench.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Microsoft leaders warned Bill Gates over ‘inappropriate’ emails.
description: Mr. Gates, who at the time was Microsoft’s chairman, had asked a female employee out on a date, a Microsoft spokesman said.
content: Microsoft executives warned Bill Gates in 2008 about inappropriate emails he had sent to a female employee, a Microsoft spokesman said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Showdown Over Northern Ireland Has a Key Offstage Player: Biden
description: As the U.K. and the European Union begin their wrangling over details of trade with Northern Ireland, President Biden has more than a passing interest in the final result.
content: LONDON — When President Biden met Prime Minister Boris Johnson at the White House last month, one of Mr. Biden’s advisers passed him a note reminding him to raise the issue of trade tensions over Northern Ireland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Zalmay Khalilzad, Biden’s Envoy for Afghanistan, Steps Down
description: An Afghan American and a rare Trump appointee who survived into the Biden administration, Mr. Khalilzad played a central role in the U.S. exit from the country.
content: WASHINGTON — Zalmay Khalilzad, President Biden’s envoy for Afghanistan and a rare Trump appointee to remain in the new administration, is departing from the government, the State Department said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Bitcoin Comes to the Big Board
description: An exchange-traded fund tied to the cryptocurrency is set to begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange, a milestone for the industry.
content: Bitcoin has been on a tear in recent weeks, approaching record high prices above $60,000, as crypto enthusiasts anticipate history in the making. Tomorrow morning, ProShares will launch a long-awaiting exchange-traded fund on the New York Stock Exchange linked to Bitcoin futures, the firm and the exchange told DealBook. The E.T.F. will give investors exposure to Bitcoin without having to hold the cryptocurrency directly, via any ordinary brokerage account.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Keeping Older Drivers Protected on the Road
description: Safe driving is possible for many people in their 70s, 80s and beyond, provided they take steps to maintain their skills.
content: Highway safety experts have long been concerned about a possible epidemic of accidents and fatalities as people in their 70s, 80s and beyond continued to drive. The children of older drivers have worried along with them, sometimes going to extremes to commandeer the keys of their aging parents when reasoning fails to get them off the road.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: intrinsic
description: This word has appeared in 120 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
title: F.D.A. to Allow ‘Mix and Match’ Approach for Covid Booster Shots
description: The agency may act this week, when it is expected to authorize booster shots for recipients of the Moderna and Johnson & Johnson vaccines.
content: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration is planning to allow Americans to receive a different Covid-19 vaccine as a booster than the one they initially received, a move that could reduce the appeal of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine and provide flexibility to doctors and other vaccinators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Journey to the Farthest Reaches of the Food World
description: “Gastro Obscura” by Dylan Thuras, an author of “Atlas Obscura,” and Cecily Wong chronicles surprising comestibles, from an eel smokehouse in New York to the cafeteria at Chernobyl.
content: You cannot help but be drawn to “Gastro Obscura,” a compendium of culinary oddities. Organized geographically, it offers thumbnails of the uncommon food experiences that exist across the globe, including in all 50 states. There is the remote eel smokehouse in Hancock, N.Y., east of Binghamton, and the list of Chinese restaurants in the most far-flung locations on the globe, like Tang’s on the island of Tromsoya north of the Arctic Circle. There are cod tongues in Eastern Canada; pickles brined in Kool-Aid, a specialty in the Mississippi Delta; and the cafeteria on the grounds of the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone, open to tourists who must pass through a radiation detector. The book, which provides travel information, also has lists like traditional soda jerk terms and Japan’s rarest fruits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: Hello? This Is Colombia’s Antimachismo Hotline.
description: A new hotline in Bogotá takes calls from men struggling with jealousy, control and fear — and challenges long-held assumptions about masculinity.
content: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — The calls are often urgent and pleading.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Seattle, Long Ready for Another Pro Team, Embraces the Kraken
description: A week into the season, the N.H.L.’s newest team is 1-1-1 on the ice, and undefeated in the contest of local public opinion. Nowhere is that more obvious than Seattle’s original hockey bar.
content: SEATTLE — Will latte-sipping Seattle embrace the brawny N.H.L. and its newest team?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: A Leader They Didn’t Choose
description: How some tenants in Los Angeles may lose the voice they found on the City Council.
content: In the past two editions of my newsletter, I wrote about Nithya Raman, a progressive Los Angeles City Councilwoman who took office in 2020 and how her political opposition organized itself before and after the election. We met Richard Close and Cindy Chvatal, the heads of two powerful homeowners’ associations in Raman’s district. Today’s newsletter is about the renters in the Park La Brea housing complex, also under Raman’s jurisdiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: A regional Fed analysis suggests Biden’s stimulus is temporarily stoking inflation.
description: The American Rescue Plan could be pushing inflation up slightly and temporarily, a Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco analysis said.
content: Inflation is likely getting a temporary boost from the $1.9 trillion coronavirus relief package that the Biden administration ushered in early this year, new Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco research released on Monday suggested.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman and Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Succession at Scholastic Seemed to Be a Shock, Even to the New Chairwoman
description: The powerhouse children’s publisher, known for Harry Potter, had been passed from father to son until Iole Lucchese, a top executive, was given control.
content: When her phone buzzed on June 6, Iole Lucchese was still absorbing a shock that had come the day before. Her longtime boss, M. Richard Robinson Jr., the chairman and chief executive of the Scholastic publishing company, had died suddenly while taking a walk with one of his sons and his former wife on Martha’s Vineyard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins and Benjamin Novak
title: In Hungary’s Heartland, Orban Faces a Unified Challenge to His Rule
description: The country’s normally fractious opposition has rallied around a conservative mayor who just might be able to oust the authoritarian prime minister after more than a decade.
content: HODMEZOVASARHELY, Hungary — A devout Catholic, he abhors abortion as “murder” and once voted for Viktor Orban, Hungary’s pugnacious populist leader, impressed by his promises to root out corruption and end the disarray left by years of leftist rule.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Oct. 18, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Oct. 18, 2021.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Swing-Arm Lamps
description: Because they’re just so convenient.
content: Swing-arm sconces put light exactly where you need it. And they’re especially helpful in spaces where you don’t have wiring for a ceiling fixture or a place for a free-standing lamp.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Decoding Kyrsten Sinema’s Style
description: Sometimes a dress is just a dress. Sometimes it’s a strategy.
content: Senator Kyrsten Sinema may have been in Europe recently on a fund-raising trip and out of reach of the activists who have dogged her footsteps, frustrated with her obstruction of President Biden’s social spending bill. But despite the fact her office has been keeping her itinerary under wraps, were those protesters able to follow her overseas, there’s a good chance they would be able to find her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Vineyard
title: Lee Jung-jae Thinks ‘Squid Game’ Critics Should Watch It Again
description: In an interview, the star of the Netflix phenomenon discusses the message of the series and possibilities for a Season 2.
content: This interview contains spoilers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Powell said that backing the war in Iraq was a ‘blot’ on his record.
description: As secretary of state, he reluctantly supported President George W. Bush’s push to invade Iraq after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
content: As secretary of state, Colin L. Powell was a reluctant warrior in President George W. Bush’s push to invade Iraq after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. He warned the president that the invasion could destabilize the Middle East, upset oil markets and divert political will and resources from the unfinished fight against Al Qaeda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib
title: F.B.I. Is Working in Haiti to Recover Kidnapped Missionaries
description: The United States has a team on the ground to try to secure the release of 17 people taken by a gang in the latest example of the violence that is leaving Haitians desperate.
content: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — The American government has a team on the ground in Haiti working with the American Embassy and the local authorities to recover a group of kidnapped missionaries and their children, White House and law-enforcement officials said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: Lawmakers question whether Amazon executives, including Jeff Bezos, misled Congress.
description: A bipartisan group told the company that they were considering referring their concerns to the Justice Department for a potential criminal inquiry.
content: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan group of lawmakers pressed Amazon’s chief executive on Monday to respond to allegations that its executives provided a congressional inquiry with false answers to questions about its house-brand products.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: An Official Wizard in New Zealand Loses His Job
description: The city of Christchurch has paid Ian Brackenbury Channell, 88, about $10,000 per year since 1998 for “acts of wizardry and other wizard-like services.” But he has been condemned recently for his jokes about women.
content: No industry is safe from the realities of layoffs. Not even wizarding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht and Henrik Pryser Libell
title: In Norway Attack, ‘Sharp Object,’ Not Arrows, Killed 5, Police Say
description: The Norwegian police on Monday said that while a hunting bow had been used in last week’s rampage, the victims, four women and a man, were stabbed to death.
content: OSLO — The attacker who went on a rampage in a town in Norway killed his five victims using a “sharp object,” not a bow and arrow as had been widely reported, the Norwegian police announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Explaining the Impact of Redistricting in Texas, Visually
description: When Texas Republicans revealed their new congressional map last month, our reporters and graphics editors used maps and data to examine the effects.
content: Once a decade, the Texas legislature — or, more precisely, whatever party happens to be in power — has the chance to redraw the map of the state’s congressional districts. Redistricting, which is taking place all over the country, is a process that reconfigures electoral boundaries to make sure the changes in population are fairly apportioned to each district. Politicians will sometimes carve up states into oddly shaped districts designed to lock in or even expand their power in upcoming elections, a process known as gerrymandering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: What Does Horror Taste Like? ‘Carnage Asada’ and Bloody Cocktails
description: An unlikely side effect of the pandemic: An uptick in terror-themed restaurants with creative names and even more creative menus.
content: There are many ways restaurant décor can say welcome: fresh flowers, linen tablecloths, soft lighting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Looking for a Star? Check the Dodgers’ Bench.
description: For the Dodgers, deep pockets and extreme ambition make everyone expendable. Just ask players like Kiké Hernández and Joc Pederson, who took their October magic elsewhere.
content: ATLANTA — The Los Angeles Dodgers are not for everyone. Sometimes, young players need to leave when they become eligible for free agency if they want regular playing time. And sometimes, accomplished players are brushed aside because the Dodgers have the ability and the will to acquire other, more accomplished players.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips, Matthew Goldstein and Ephrat Livni
title: S.E.C. Describes the GameStop Frenzy, but Not What to Do About It
description: A long-anticipated report did not suggest any policy changes in response to the meme stock frenzy that caused some little-regarded shares to soar.
content: The frenzied trading in shares of GameStop and other so-called meme stocks last January led to big losses for some hedge funds, an outcry from retail investors who were suddenly shut out of buying and calls on Capitol Hill to overhaul rules governing the markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Collapse: Inside Lebanon’s Worst Economic Meltdown in More Than a Century’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about the effects of the economic crisis in Lebanon from looking at images and reading first-person accounts. Then, they will read an Opinion essay about the collapse.
content: Featured Article: “Collapse: Inside Lebanon’s Worst Economic Meltdown in More Than a Century” text by Ben Hubbard and photographs by Bryan Denton
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A Youth Football Mission to Save Children and Church
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, October 18, 2021.
content: “It’s sad because I think that they’re making a terrible mistake and they’re injuring children’s brains. It’s the second child abuse crisis in the Catholic Church.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Atlanta Bought in Bulk to Replace the Irreplaceable
description: For many teams, losing Ronald Acuña Jr. would have been a crushing blow. To the Braves’ Alex Anthopoulos, it was a puzzle to solve. He seems to have the right pieces.
content: ATLANTA — The Atlanta Braves had played more than half of their schedule, they still had a losing record, and then things really got bad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jake Halpern
title: Between Fear and the Need to Feel Alive
description: The clearest views in life come from standing at the edge of a scary cliff. Which is why I want my son by my side.
content: Not long ago, my 12-year-old son, Lucian, and I were standing on the knife’s edge. I mean this quite literally. We had just completed a grueling, four-day hike in Maine that culminated with us climbing Mount Katahdin. At its summit, Katahdin has an extremely dramatic, mile-long ridge known as the Knife Edge, that looks like the back of a stegosaurus. It connects the mountain’s two most dramatic peaks. The ridge is narrow, less than an arm-length wide in places, with massive drops on both sides. It’s scary and quite dangerous: The mountain has claimed at least 17 lives. We knew we had to be careful, but in an odd way, the danger was part of the allure. Lucian and I were both craving a bit of risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Heath’s Shades of Winter
description: Winter Seasonal, a new palette of glazes from Heath Ceramics, features cooler options for the season.
content: Heath Ceramics has history. The company was created in Sausalito, Calif., in 1948, by Edith Heath, a potter and artist, and her husband, Brian Heath. It has long been known for its simple, utilitarian shapes and often neutral glazes; the pieces fit seamlessly in the midcentury aesthetic. The company suffered some hard times, but in 2003 it was bought by Robin Petravic and Catherine Bailey, a husband and wife team. They opened a studio and store in Los Angeles in 2008 and added linens, pillows and other accessories to the inventory. This fall the company has introduced its plates, bowls, vases and mugs in a new set of glazes called Winter Seasonal, in a palette that runs from dark purple and cranberry red to paler azure and lavender.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: ‘Succession’ Recap, Season 3, Episode 1: Action Stations, Let’s Go
description: In the Season 3 premiere, the Roys and their surrogates hustled to secure allies in the coming fight between father and son.
content: The “Succession” Season 3 premiere opens with a shot of two helicopters speeding across the sky, with a stunning mountain landscape in the distance. It’s an immediate reminder of what this show is about: ridiculously rich people, rushing from one ritzy location to another, doing endless damage control while living the highest lives imaginable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By André Wheeler
title: Actress Yvonne Orji Reflects on the End of ‘Insecure,’ and Tells T a Joke
description: The comedian looks back on her years working on the career-defining show and demonstrates her trademark wit.
content: “Ease and flow.” This is the mantra that has guided the Nigerian American actress and comedian Yvonne Orji — who plays Molly Carter, a quick-witted, romantically challenged lawyer on the HBO series “Insecure” — through the dizzying past year. “I know what you can accomplish with hustle and grind,” says the 37-year-old, who earned two degrees (in liberal arts and public health) from George Washington University before setting her sights on Hollywood. “But I didn’t know what you can accomplish with ease and flow. It’s been a shock to my system.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Review: ‘The Red and the Black’ Is Sumptuous, but Safe
description: Based on the 1830 novel by Stendhal, Pierre Lacotte’s new production for the Paris Opera Ballet is an old-fashioned costume drama.
content: PARIS — “The Red and the Black,” Pierre Lacotte’s sumptuous new production for the Paris Opera Ballet, which opened on Saturday at the Palais Garnier, contains many contradictions embodied by that dance company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong
title: Inside the N.Y.C. Neighborhood With the Fastest Growing Asian Population
description: In a corner of Queens, a fivefold increase in Asian residents since 2010 is transforming the area’s restaurants, housing and politics.
content: Yumpling, a Taiwanese eatery, opened its first brick-and-mortar restaurant in August 2020, when New York City was in an uneasy limbo between waves of the coronavirus. Indoor dining was still banned, but the owners had signed the lease right before the pandemic and could not keep paying rent on an empty storefront.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: In the Disturbing ‘Dana H.,’ Whose Voice Is It Anyway?
description: Deirdre O’Connell brilliantly lip-syncs the testimony of a woman abducted by a white supremacist in a play by Lucas Hnath.
content: Dana Higginbotham had recently lost her job as a chaplain in the psychiatric unit of a Florida hospital when, in 1997, she was abducted by one of her former patients, a methed-up ex-con named Jim.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning and Brian X. Chen
title: Apple unveils new MacBook computers and updated AirPods.
description: The tech giant rolled back some of the changes it had made to its laptops, getting rid of the unpopular Touch Bar and re-adding ports for an HDMI cable and an SD memory card.
content: Apple on Monday unveiled in an hourlong virtual event new MacBook computers powered by Apple-made processors and an updated model of its popular AirPods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: As Starbucks Workers Seek a Union, Company Officials Converge on Stores
description: A push in the Buffalo area could produce the first union at company-owned stores in the U.S. But backers say moves by management are having a chilling effect.
content: BUFFALO — During her decade-plus at Starbucks, Michelle Eisen says she has endured her share of workplace stress. She points to the company’s increased use of productivity goals, inadequate attention to training and periods of understaffing or high turnover.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Dawn Hudson, the C.E.O. of the Motion Picture Academy, will step down in 2023.
description: Under her leadership, the Academy has taken steps to diversify and expand its membership.
content: Dawn Hudson, the chief executive of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, is beginning a long goodbye from the job she’s held since 2011.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: U.K. Leaders Praise Slain Lawmaker Amid Heightened Security Concerns
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson and members of Parliament paid tribute to David Amess, who was fatally stabbed last week.
content: LONDON — Politicians from across the political divide on Monday united in tribute to David Amess, the British lawmaker killed in an assault last week that has heightened concerns about security arrangements for members of Parliament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.7 Million Homes in California
description: An Edwardian house in Oakland, a Craftsman home in South Pasadena and a midcentury ranch in Sonoma.
content: This house is on a wide street lined with other stately Edwardian houses, similarly updated with an eye toward maintaining historic character. The owners of this home changed the color of the exterior paint from pale blue to deep gray, with touches of black accenting the original entry and clinker-brick porch, which sit underneath a row of original decorative corbels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Walk It Off, Again: Atlanta Widens Lead Over Dodgers
description: Thrilling wins in consecutive games, both decided in their last at-bat, have Atlanta heading to Los Angeles with some breathing room ahead of Game 3.
content: ATLANTA — Fortunes never change more quickly than they do in October.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Olivia Horn
title: The War on Drugs Can’t Stop Searching for Answers in the Music
description: Fatherhood reshaped the frontman Adam Granduciel’s world, and a collaborative spirit animated the band on its fifth album, “I Don’t Live Here Anymore.”
content: The first time Adam Granduciel hinted at a possible career change, he tossed it off as a humorous aside. “Basically my whole family are educators,” he said in a video interview last month from his Los Angeles home. “Perhaps it is also my destiny. Who knows?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Justice Department Asks Supreme Court to Block Texas Abortion Law
description: Saying the law is “plainly unconstitutional,” the department also asked the court to add the case to its docket in its current term.
content: WASHINGTON — In a forceful brief filed Monday, the Biden administration urged the Supreme Court to temporarily block a Texas law that bans most abortions in the state while a legal challenge moves forward, calling the law “plainly unconstitutional.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Russia hits a Covid death record.
content: Russia exceeded 1,000 deaths in a 24-hour period on Saturday, for the first time since the pandemic began. Russia broke another record yesterday with more than 34,000 new infections registered in the previous 24 hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Hey Parler, My Blue City Isn’t Turning Red
description: Nashville may be having an identity crisis. But our moral commitment to equality will never change.
content: NASHVILLE — When NPR’s tech reporter, Bobby Allyn, tweeted last week that the social media site Parler was moving its headquarters from Nevada to Nashville, a single word came to my mind — a word this newspaper will not publish, no matter that it is the only word in the English language truly appropriate to the situation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Myanmar Announces Amnesty for Thousands of Anti-Coup Protesters
description: The junta, which seized power in February, said it was releasing the prisoners to mark the Lighting Festival, a three-day holiday that begins Tuesday.
content: Myanmar’s ruling junta announced on Monday that it would free more than 5,600 anti-regime protesters this week in its first significant release of political prisoners since seizing power in a Feb. 1 coup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Apathy and Wariness of Kremlin Leave Russians Unvaccinated
description: The country hit 1,000 deaths in a 24-hour period for the first time since the pandemic began, reflecting the risks of having a low vaccination rate.
content: MOSCOW — After Sofia Kravetskaya got vaccinated with Russia’s Sputnik V vaccine last December, she became a pariah on the Moscow playground where she takes her young daughter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Diver Discovers 900-Year-Old Sword Dating to the Crusades
description: The sword, recovered off the coast of Israel, most likely belonged to a knight who fell into the sea or lost the weapon in battle, experts said.
content: Shlomi Katzin attached a GoPro camera to his forehead, slipped on his diving fins and jumped into the waters off the Carmel coast of Israel, eager to go exploring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Treasury Warns That Digital Currencies Could Weaken U.S. Sanctions
description: A review found that the sanctions program must be modernized to maintain its effectiveness.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration warned on Monday that digital currencies posed a threat to America’s sanctions program and said in a new report that the United States needed to modernize how sanctions were deployed so that they remained an effective national security tool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Joe Manchin Versus West Virginia
description: On climate and children, he's hurting his own constituents.
content: President Biden’s policy agenda is hanging by a thread. And the reason can be summarized in two words: Joe Manchin. (Well, also Kyrsten Sinema, but does anyone know what’s going on with her?)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Do You Experience Climate Anxiety?
description: Can widespread eco-distress be a catalyst for climate solutions?
content: Do you experience anxiety, grief or fear about climate change? What has that felt like? How have you coped with it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: From Graffiti in the Shadows to Designing an Observation Deck in the Clouds
description: There’s a new way to take in the skyline. For Kenzo Digital, a lifelong New Yorker who designed its dreamlike interior, the city was his muse.
content: For much of the pandemic, Midtown Manhattan has struggled. Office buildings have lost their buzz, which has affected local restaurants and other businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Colin Powell dies of complications from Covid.
description: Colin L. Powell, who in four decades of public life served as the nation’s top soldier, diplomat and national security adviser, and whose speech at the United Nations in 2003 helped pave the way for the United States to go to war in Iraq, died on Monday. He was 84.
content: Colin L. Powell, who in four decades of public life served as the nation’s top soldier, diplomat and national security adviser, and whose speech at the United Nations in 2003 helped pave the way for the United States to go to war in Iraq, died on Monday. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China’s Economy Continues to Slow, Rattled by Real Estate and Energy
description: Growth of 4.9 percent shows the country’s huge industrial sector has run into trouble. But exports and services are looking strong.
content: BEIJING — Steel mills have faced power cuts. Computer chip shortages have slowed car production. Troubled property companies have purchased less construction material. Floods have disrupted business in north-central China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Drake’s ‘Certified Lover Boy’ Spends a Fourth Week at No. 1
description: The Houston rapper Don Toliver opens at No. 2, while the music industry turns its attention to the numbers for Adele’s comeback single.
content: Drake returns to No. 1 on this week’s Billboard album chart, while the Houston rapper Don Toliver opens at No. 2 and the music industry keeps a close eye on the numbers for a song that will impact next week’s chart: Adele’s comeback single.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Robert Jimison, Jessica Cheung, Sydney Harper, Rob Szypko, Mike Benoist, Lisa Chow, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: Why Are All Eyes on the Virginia Governor’s Race?
description: Both parties are deeply invested in a contest that could reveal much about the state of American politics in the Biden era.
content: The Virginia governor’s race — the first competitive election in the United States since President Biden took office — will be a major test of the national political environment before the midterms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: A Sweeping New History Looks Back at 100 Years of Black Filmmaking
description: Wil Haygood’s “Colorization” feels crisp and urgent while covering a lot of ground: from the earliest pioneers to the careers of Sidney Poitier, Lena Horne, Spike Lee and many others.
content: The first chapter of Wil Haygood’s elegant and well-made book of history, “Colorization: One Hundred Years of Black Films in a White World,” is titled “Movie Night at Woodrow Wilson’s White House.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: A Move to Rein In Cancer-Causing ‘Forever Chemicals’
description: Michael Regan, the E.P.A. administrator, wants to limit a class of chemicals that has been linked to cancer and is found in everything from drinking water to furniture.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Monday said it would require chemical manufacturers to test and publicly report the amount of a family of chemicals known as PFAS that is contained in household items like tape, nonstick pans and stain-resistant furniture, the first step toward reducing their presence in drinking water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin George Andrews
title: How a Nuclear Bomb Could Save Earth From a Stealthy Asteroid
description: An atomic blast is not the preferred solution for planetary defense, but 3-D models are helping scientists prepare for a worst-case scenario.
content: One day, astronomers may spot an asteroid months away from a cataclysmic rendezvous with Earth. Our only chance of survival at such a late stage would be to try to use a nuclear explosive to obliterate it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: How to Prepare Your Kid for a Coronavirus Exposure at School
description: Because even classrooms with the strictest safety protocols might have to deal with some cases.
content: Now that kids are back in the classroom, there’s a very real possibility that they may be exposed to the coronavirus, and may need to be tested — or isolate. This can be alarming for parents, and frightening for some children. Kids may also be disappointed if they have to miss out on certain activities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: A new antiviral coronavirus pill.
content: Molnupiravir, an antiviral medication made by Merck, could herald a not-too-distant future when a simple pill could keep people infected with the coronavirus from dying or falling severely ill. The drug is easy to distribute and can be taken at home. Trial results showed it halved the risk of hospitalization and death among high-risk people early in their infections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon
title: Colin Powell, Boosters, Russia: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Review: ‘Designing Women,’ With 30 Years of Pent-up Angst to Air
description: Linda Bloodworth-Thomason’s popular TV series comes to the stage with its sisterhood intact. But at times this revival feels a lot like a pretext to vent.
content: The women of Sugarbaker and Associates are ready to unload, and it’s easy to see why — the last time we heard from them was almost 30 years ago, when the hit sitcom “Designing Women” went off the air. That’s a lot of time to keep things bottled up. But now Julia, Suzanne and Mary Jo are back (Charlene is mostly on break), and reigniting the flame of Southern-style sisterhood in a new play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat and Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Video Shows Louisiana Sheriff’s Deputy Slamming Black Woman to the Ground
description: The A.C.L.U. said that the Jefferson Parish Sheriff’s Office had opened an investigation into the violent encounter. The woman was treated at a hospital, and no charges were filed against her.
content: The video is short but harrowing. The camera lens quickly zooms past a car and focuses on the scene behind it: A sheriff’s deputy in Louisiana, who towers over a small Black woman, is slamming her onto the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Robert Haas, Financier and Aerial Photographer, Dies at 74
description: He specialized in leveraged buyouts in the 1980s, shot distant landscapes and wildlife from helicopters, then collected so many motorcycles that he opened a museum.
content: Robert Haas, a financier who in his 50s used his wealth to go in a markedly different direction, becoming a published aerial photographer, and then in his 60s began collecting vintage and custom-made motorcycles and creating a Texas museum to display them, died on Sept. 28 in a hospital in Dallas. He was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham and Elizabeth Dias
title: For Missionary Group in a Fragile Haiti, Charity Turns to Chaos
description: An organization based in Ohio and founded by Amish and Mennonites has been swept up in the violence roiling the country.
content: Christian missionary workers typically labor in obscurity, running medical clinics, building wells and delivering Bibles without fanfare — until crisis erupts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Nuwer
title: A Taste for Pangolin Meat and the Fall of an African Wildlife Cartel
description: Yunhua Lin and associates had turned Malawi into an ivory, rhino horn and pangolin scale trafficking hub. His prison sentence could aid the fight against poaching.
content: Hundreds of poachers are arrested each year for killing elephants, rhinos, pangolins and other animals in Africa. Yet the problem persists, because there is always a ready supply of desperate men to take the place of those put behind bars. Higher-level criminals, on the other hand — those who really drive the international illegal wildlife trade — almost always evade justice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith and Melissa Eddy
title: Powerful German Newspaper Ousts Editor After Times Report on Workplace Behavior
description: The editor, Julian Reichelt, had been accused of abusing his power involving a relationship a junior employee at Bild, a tabloid owned by the media giant Axel Springer.
content: Germany’s most powerful newspaper removed its top editor Monday after months of defending his sexual relationships with women in the workplace as the scandal began to envelop the paper’s globally ambitious parent company, Axel Springer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Public health in crisis
content: At the beginning of the summer, when it looked like the U.S. was turning the corner on the pandemic, my colleagues Danielle Ivory and Mike Baker set out to answer a question: How prepared are local and state health departments for the next pandemic?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Foxconn unveils prototypes as it pushes to become an electric-car maker.
description: The company known for making iPhones presented three electric vehicles that can serve as a basis for working with car companies.
content: Foxconn, the Taiwanese electronics giant that assembles Apple’s iPhones, on Monday showed off the first physical fruits of its effort to become a major player in electric vehicles: a luxury sedan, a sport utility vehicle and a bus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: Goldman Sachs wins approval to buy out its partner in China.
description: The move will give the Wall Street giant complete ownership over its Chinese investment banking operations.
content: Goldman Sachs has won approval to take full ownership of a joint venture in China, enabling the Wall Street firm to expand its operations in the country at a time when Beijing has made moves to open up its financial sector.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker and Danielle Ivory
title: Why Public Health Faces a Crisis Across the U.S.
description: An examination of hundreds of health departments around the country shows that the nation may be less prepared for the next pandemic than it was for the current one.
content: PORT ANGELES, Wash. — As she leaves work, Dr. Allison Berry keeps a vigilant eye on her rearview mirror, watching the vehicles around her, weighing if she needs to take a more circuitous route home. She must make sure nobody finds out where she lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: A Century-Long ‘Reign of Error’ for a Supreme Court Typo
description: A sweeping statement in a 1928 opinion about property rights was revised soon after it was issued. But the error lived on.
content: “When we issue an opinion, we are aware that every word that we write can have consequences, sometimes enormous consequences,” Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. said last month. “So we have to be careful about every single thing that we say.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Multiple myeloma is a rare cancer that seems to strike at random.
description: Colin Powell had a form of blood cancer that saps natural immunity and also undermines the effects of vaccines like the ones used against Covid-19.
content: Colin L. Powell, the first Black secretary of state, had multiple myeloma: a form of blood cancer that hobbles the immune system and makes vaccines, including those for Covid-19, less effective.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Removing a Statue of Thomas Jefferson from City Hall
description: The 19th-century depiction of Jefferson is on track to be removed from the City Council’s chamber after a push by its members.
content: It’s Monday. We’ll look at a statue of Thomas Jefferson that will be on its way out of City Hall — if a hearing today ends with a vote to remove it. And we’ll check in on someone we met a few weeks ago who’s finally checking out of the Manhattan hotel where he has lived for 17 months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames, Scott Cacciola and Sopan Deb
title: N.B.A. East Preview: The Bucks Aren’t Finished Yet
description: The Bucks might be better, while the Sixers and Nets are playing wait-and-see with key stars. The Eastern Conference could play out in several ways.
content: Here lie the N.B.A.’s most compelling story lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Democrats Are Courting Manchin on Their Agenda. Here’s What He Wants.
description: The West Virginia Democrat could decide the fate of President Biden’s top legislative priority, and he has not been shy about outlining the kinds of changes he wants to see.
content: WASHINGTON — If Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia ruled the world, Democrats’ marquee domestic policy bill would look much different than what President Biden and top Democrats have proposed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Karabell
title: Just How High Could the Dow Go?
description: The markets going up even as wages stagnate is not a sign of a rigged system.
content: Twenty-two years ago this fall, a new book with the provocative title “Dow 36,000,” by James K. Glassman and Kevin A. Hassett, was published to great fanfare — and not a little derision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Paula Badosa Outlasts Victoria Azarenka to Win Indian Wells
description: Badosa won her first top-tier title on Sunday with a hard-fought 7-6 (5), 2-6, 7-6 (2) victory over Azarenka in a final that required three hours and four minutes.
content: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — In its usual March dates, the BNP Paribas Open has been a launching pad for  major talent in recent years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Acme Turns to Japan to Season Its Latest Smoked Salmon
description: Acme Smoked Fish in Brooklyn uses shichimi togarashi in this new offering.
content: Smoked salmon has a new edge. Acme Smoked Fish, in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, has introduced smoked salmon seasoned with shichimi togarashi, a Japanese spice blend, giving it a subtle but distinctive chile and citrus kick. The blend includes red chile, sesame seeds, orange peel, seaweed and other spices. This is not the salmon to put on an everything bagel. Go for plain or roll the salmon in nori, perhaps smeared with cream cheese.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: A.L.C.S. Provides a ‘Moment of Pride’ for Puerto Rico
description: A matchup between the Astros and the Red Sox is loaded with representation of the Caribbean island. Some friendships had to be put on hold.
content: HOUSTON — During a lull in the sixth inning of Game 1 of the American League Championship Series on Friday, as umpires sorted out a play, Houston Astros catcher Martín Maldonado walked back to his position behind the plate. Waiting there for his turn to bat, Boston Red Sox catcher Christian Vázquez smacked Maldonado on the chest and threw his arm around him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: 4 Questions About the Supply Chain
description: Supply chain issues have made all kinds of products — paint and lumber, certain foods, clothing and electronics — harder to find.
content: Supply chain issues have made all kinds of products — paint and lumber, certain foods, clothing and electronics — harder to find.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu
title: On the Scene: Groceries in 15 Minutes
description: An air horn blares whenever an online order lands. Here’s what I saw.
content: An air horn blares whenever an online order lands. Here’s what I saw.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis
title: How Much Do You Know About Benin?
description: Can you find Benin on a map? What else do you know about this African country with about 12 million people?
content: Can you find Benin on a map? What else do you know about this African country with about 12 million people?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Cold Seafood, Hot Spices
description: Shrimp, octopus and fish bathe in chile-laced marinades at Mariscos El Submarino.
content: Shrimp, octopus and fish bathe in chile-laced marinades at Mariscos El Submarino.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $2.7 Million in California
description: An Edwardian house in Oakland, a Craftsman home in South Pasadena and a midcentury ranch in Sonoma.
content: An Edwardian house in Oakland, a Craftsman home in South Pasadena and a midcentury ranch in Sonoma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Colin Powell Was Among World’s ‘Greatest Leaders,’ Austin Says
description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin described Colin Powell as a “tremendous personal friend and mentor” following Mr. Powell’s death from Covid-19 complications.
content: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin described Colin Powell as a “tremendous personal friend and mentor” following Mr. Powell’s death from Covid-19 complications.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By National Transportation Safety Board
title: Metro Train Derailments Could Have Been ‘Catastrophic,’ Official Says
description: The National Transportation Safety Board said that the Metro system in Washington removed more than half of its subway cars from service as federal investigators scrutinized a surge in train-alignment “failures.”
content: The National Transportation Safety Board said that the Metro system in Washington removed more than half of its subway cars from service as federal investigators scrutinized a surge in train-alignment “failures.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott J. Ross
title: Tell T a Joke | Yvonne Orji
description: The actress pokes fun at her mother.
content: The actress pokes fun at her mother.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phoebe Lett
title: Aack! A Millennial’s Audio Odyssey Through the ‘Cathy’ Comic Strip
description: The comedian Jamie Loftus returns with another limited-run podcast, this time exploring white boomer women through the lens of a much-maligned comic strip.
content: For some stand-up comedians, podcasts resemble an open-mic night with no red light telling them to wrap it up. The medium presents an opportunity to chat with friends and riff on whatever strikes their fancy, for hours and hours. Not so with Jamie Loftus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Food That’s Worth Waiting For
description: Take your time with these garlicky chicken thighs.
content: Good morning. I made a quesadilla the other day: ham and Swiss cheese with some mango salsa I had in the fridge, with sour cream and Jamaican hot sauce. I took my time making it, too, cooking the tortillas slowly in butter so they crisped and pillowed, flipping them back and forth a few times before I fished the package out of the pan to rest for a moment, then cut it in eighths. My wife grew impatient and asked: “What is that, a slow-food quesadilla?”
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘History Will Not Be Kind to Senator Joe Manchin’
description: Readers criticize Mr. Manchin as someone putting his interests ahead of the country’s. Also: Racial equity in child care; a civil conversation; social media.
